availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: St. Louis, Missouri, professor and U.S. Army general. Native of Sinsheim, Baden, Germany. Son of Moritz Sigel and Anna Marie Pauline Lictenauer Sigel. Graduated from Karlsruhe Academy in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg, Germany, and attended law school at Heidelberg University. Married to Elsie Dulon in January 1854. Father of Robert Sigel, Paul Sigel, Rudolph Sigel, and Lelia Sigel. Soldier in Army of Grand Duke of Baden from 1843 to 1848. Commander of Freikorps battalion of German revolutionaries from 1848 to 1849. Appointed Minister of War in provisional government of Liberals in 1849. Language tutor and fencing instructor in New York from 1852 to 1853. Opened a cigar store in New York in 1853. Commissioned Major in 5th New York Militia in 1854. Professor at the German-American Institute, or Feldner School, in New York from 1855 to 1857 and the Deutsches Institut in St. Louis from 1857 to 1861. Member of the Turner Society in New York and St. Louis. Co-founder of monthly journal the Interpreter. Colonel in 3rd Missouri Infantry from May 4, 1861, to May 16, 1861. Served in U.S. Volunteers as brigadier general from May 17, 1861, to March 21, 1862, and as major general from March 21, 1862, to May 4, 1865.

ab.bibl: Stephen D. Engle, Yankee Dutchman: The Life of Franz Sigel (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1993) iv-vi, 2, 6-7, 34, 37-38, 42-43, 293. _ Veterans Administration Pension Payment Cards, 1907-1933_ NARA Microfilm Publication, M850, Record Group 15, Roll 2056 (Accessed via Ancestry.com). Historical Register and Dictionary of the United States Army: From Its Organization, September 29, 1789, to March 2, 1903, vol 1 (Washington: Govt. Print. Off., 1903), 28, 30, 886.
